page.title: 10CHESTERFIELD CANAL
page.content: ON THE WESTERN BOUNDARY OF THE GRID IS THE CHESTERFIELD CANAL. ONE OF THE EARLIEST CANALS OF THE CANAL AGE ,IT WAS BEGUN BY JAMES BRINDLEY WHO SURVEYED THE ROUTE PRIOR TO THE COMMENCEMENT OF CONSTRUCTION IN 1789. THE CANAL WAS FINALLY OPENED ON 4TH JUNE 1777 AFTER BRINDLEYS DEATH BUT HIS ORIGINAL IDEAS WERE UTILISED. THE CANAL RUNS FOR 46 MILES FROM THE RIVER TRENT TO CHESTERFIELD. THE CANAL JOINS THE RIVER AT THE BASIN AT WEST STOCKWITH.ALONG THE ORIGINAL ROUTE WERE 65 LOCKS AND TWO TUNNELS,ONE OF THESE BEING 2895 YARDS LONG ,A REMARKABLE ACHIEVEMENT BEARING IN MIND THE ENGINEERING EQUIPMENT IN USE AT THE TIME.THE FIRST FIVE LOCKS WERE WIDE LOCKS TO ENABLE BARGES TO TRAVEL FROM THE RIVER TO RETFORD.INDEED THE CORPORATION OF THAT TOWN PROVIDED THE FUNDS FOR THIS PURPOSE.
